comments.text:

America where everyone has access to cheap fluoridated toothpaste.

comments.author: Mr Shane

comments.text:
+Vegetarians eat Poop my diet is simply, less sugar, less refined flour 
and eat as "natural" as I possibly can.
comments.author: ItSheHe HeSheIt

comments.text:
+ItSheHe HeSheIt
I agree. That's why, in a previous comment, I compared the introduction of 
fluoride to public water, to the production of leaded gasoline in the 
1920's. There were lots of scientific reports (obviously supported by some 
oil companies) that concluded that there was nothing to worry about. It 
took more than 50 years later to convince the public that it was a serious 
health issue and that something had to be done about it. But before that, 
this was just a "conspiracy theory."
comments.author: Vegetarians eat Poop

comments.text:
+Vegetarians eat Poop not all org sites are equal, and not all scientific 
studies are equall as well! We should be careful about the background of 
the sites, and focus more on the legitimacy and accuracy of contents.

There are so many health associtations around, Amercian heart 
association...etc... and many people think they are trustable. I am not a 
conspiracy theorist but there has been numerous reports and accusations 
saying that many of these organisations are closely tied with private 
corporations, ie received big sponserships etc... well I have no direct 
proof myself but I cannot rule out all the possibilities. AHA was one of 
the organisations that first demonzied saturated fat and promote low fat 
high carbs diet and obviously there are quite a few  science 
litertures revealed that saturated fat is actually not as evil as they 
claimed, and moderate amount of good fat intake is actually beneficial to 
our health.

There are studies that were conducted by "scientists" who are sponsored by 
private corps or a particular interest groups. Some studies are 
observational ones but the mainstream media reported them as if they are 
the cause of some diseases.

The internet is flooded with all sort of info, it's not easy for any layman 
to distingush the good and reliable one without some science knowledge. 
That's why I won't rely on one single science study to make a judgement.
comments.author: ItSheHe HeSheIt

comments.text:
+Matthew Ong thanks for the link, I quickly glance through the original 
report posted on royalsociety.org.nz. It seemed to me that it is a review 
of different previous published studies rather than a proper large scale 
and long term randomised controlled trial.

Personally, I prefer not to rely on government advises for my own health, 
nor I want to part in any government's mass intervention programs. Any 
health issues that is related to "politicians", I simply cannot rely on it 
totally! I should remain skeptical.

There may be some studies showing that small amount of sodium fluoride or 
fluorosilicic acid can prevent tooth decay but so far I haven't seen a 
big studies showing that there is an increase risk of having tooth decay 
WITHOUT fluoridated water.

If the whole purpose of water fluoridation program was dental protection 
for the "general public", I think I prefer to take care of my teeth myself.

This is merely my own opinion, though.
comments.author: ItSheHe HeSheIt

comments.text:
+Matthew Ong
Yea, this is an article stating that they are using safe levels of fluoride 
in their public waters (in New Zealand), although this is not very easy to 
determine/control, because toxicity depends on the amount of water a person 
drinks a day, plus diet.. etc...
Since there is a lot conflicting evidence out there, I guess we just have 
to give this subject time, and see if any long term health issues arise out 
of this.
comments.author: Vegetarians eat Poop

comments.author: Vincent Oak

comments.text:
+Kent B.

I know comparitively nothing of this subject but it does seem relevant to 
myself. I am 6'1ft tall (roughly 181cm) and barely manage to scrape 60kg. I 
am starving almost all the time but I simply do not have the desire to eat 
,at all. I dont see myself as fat (like an anorexic might), I simply just 
dont feel like eating, even when my gut is telling me I am absolutely 
ravenous.

I tend to drink a lot too. A lot of fluids. Tea. Water. Fruit Juice. Soft 
Drinks. Whatever. I drink vastly more than I eat. At the same time, I also 
dont eat because "I had a Sandvich yesterday. I dont want one today. I had 
cereal 2 days ago. I dont want it today". I simply dont understand how 
people can eat similar foods day in, day out.

Even on the rare occasion where I do eat a lot of food, such as a holiday 
celebration like Christmas or a birthday, no matter how much I eat, even if 
it is sugary, high-calorie, fatty food - I simply do not gain weight. At 
all. I've been thin and scrawny my entire life, despite the fact that I 
virtually do nothing to expend any energy (no sports, exercise, etc).
comments.author: VenrezvonVyntari

top_comment.text:
Random question: What color would anything be if nothing existed? If there 
were no universe, no atoms, no molecules, no light; if absolutely nothing 
exists, what color would nothing be?﻿
top_comment.author: gMUNDO Vargas

comments.text: +Michael Keith Kinman Thank you
comments.author: gMUNDO Vargas

comments.text:
Black is your brain's interpretation of the absence of an optical stimulus. 
If there is no brain, there is no black. Also, "Nothing" cannot be 
"Anything" or have any attributes, such as color. If "Nothing" was a color, 
it would then be "Something" and cease to be "Nothing". Nothing can only be 
nothing. Nothing is the absence of "Everything", including color.
comments.author: Michael Keith Kinman

comments.text: +Jellal Fernandes No you do the research for me.

visible spectrum. So... whatever.

beverages while eating or directly after a meal. That is because our 
stomach might release it's contents prematurely into our bowels in reaction 
to the cold. That leads to improper digestion and might allow more 
pathogens to survive the stomach acid. If you feel that you beverage is a 
bit too cool, you might want to leave it in your mouth for a short time to 
let it warm up. If it's too cold for that, you shouldn't drink it when 
eating.

comments.author: syntek108

comments.text:
hmm, well, assuming that it takes just as much calories to warm celery as 
it takes to warm water, you'll be left with -3cal/celery
This is very rough though:
First of all, actually frozen celery (as in, coming from the freezer) may 
actually be colder than water, (depends on what settings you are using/ how 
good your freezer is), so based on that, it'll take you even more calories 
to get it up to bodily temperature.
However, second, water and ice have, as far as your average chemicals go, 
incredibly high effective heat capacity which means they are especially 
hard to heat up compared to other materials.
So while the majority of celery probably is water (just like it seems to be 
the case for most of life), since not ALL of it is, it'll be easier to heat 
up.

tl;dr: We need more science.
Also, do not try this at home with a life experiment.

void, absence, nothingness, etc. it was actually just recently that it's 
treated as an actual number to represent "zero/no value" in maths. there 
wasn't 0 in europe until 12th century. there was a representation of 
nothingness; N, which stands for nulla or nothing, so that was actually not 
a number either.

and your statement about being less than 1 means that it's singular is also 
wrong. remember, it's 0.9 calories, not calorie. -2 calories, not calorie.
comments.author: MrGamePhd

the middle ages going through an economic depression, having less access to

to sell my house, because there is a regulation for that and after that I 
receive money. I don't have to worry when I'm ill because everybody has 
mandatory health insurance. Yes there is a law for that!

+Jeremy Smith Feminism has roots in the concept of equal rights, but the 
whole notion of feminism is not equality. It is a social movement with the 
benefit of one gender. Early feminists had inequality to combat and it

based upon personal choices made by men and women. Little to no 
institutionalized sexism exists. Most "sexism" that exists is created by 
who wish to create outcomes. You cannot have equality of opportunity and 
equality of outcome. Most modern feminists seem to be interested in the 
latter. Which means they are interested in inequality that only seems like 
equality to them.

comments.text:
Totally agree. Tara presents her topics with proper sense of gravitas and 
doesn't come off as flippant or pandering to the audience by acting 
over-the-top bubbly or resort to really cheesy jokes that no one finds 
funny. By far my favorite DNews/TestTube host.

In comparison, I can't stand Laci (to the point of wanting to unsubscribe 
because she hosts so many of the videos, so to escape her completely I'd 
have to stop watching DNews). I don't even care about the controversies 
she's been involved in--I simply find her voice extremely mismatched for a 
show about dispensing knowledge (her voice is constantly on the verge of 
cracking and completely lacking the calmness/gravitas required to convey 
information with any sense of authority), and how she carries herself as a 
host feels really awkward (why scrunch up her face in huge smiles 
constantly on a show about relaying knowledge? It doesn't fit at all). Her 
personality and overall mien is simply not suitable for a news or science 
show (even for one that's trying to put a lighthearted spin on it); she'd 
be much better off on some comedic show where her uniqueness is more 
fitting, and she gets to be as colorful as she wants without distracting 
from the subject matter.

comments.author: SBwingman

comments.text:
+Paige Detro The Gay Rights movement is about LGBTQ rights, not feminism. 
 Femin short for Feminine. Nuff said. ism - : the act, practice, or process 
of doing something

: behavior like that of a specified kind of person or thing

: unfair treatment of a group of people who have a particular quality 
Being human, is not a particular quality.  

http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/egalitarianism
a belief in human equality especially with respect to social, political, 
and economic affairs
2
:  a social philosophy advocating the removal of inequalities among people.
First Known Usage. 1905

http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/feminism
Merriam Webster also states the first  known usage of feminism was 1895.
The first half of the encyclopedia is as follows "Social movement that 
seeks equal rights for women. Widespread concern for women's rights dates 
from the Enlightenment; one of the first important expressions of the 
movement was Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Woman 
(1792). The 1848 Seneca Falls Convention, convened by Elizabeth Cady 
Stanton, Lucretia Mott, and others, called for full legal equality with 
men, including full educational opportunity and equal compensation; 
thereafter the woman suffrage movement began to gather momentum. It faced 
particularly stiff resistance in the United Kingdom and the United States, 
where women gained the right to vote in 1918 and 1920, respectively. By 
mid-century a second wave of feminism emerged to address the limited nature 
of women's participation in the workplace and prevailing notions that 
tended to confine women to the home" 

only the last section mentions anything about equal rights for all, but it 
gives a timeframe. LATE 20th century as in at the earliest, possibly 1980. 
Egalitarianism existed as a word for 75 years before this. Why change the 
meaning of a word, to something that already exists, especially when the 
structure of the word would lead you to think otherwise?

comments.author: Roni First

comments.text:
Calories are to your body what gas is to your car. Car burns gas = car moves
Body burns calories =body moves (heart beats, lungs breath, intestines 
digest,  body stays warm  at 98F ect.) this is called metabolism. Body fat 
is what happens when you  eat more calories than your  body burns up every 
day. Like filling up the gas tank  to the car and instead of  letting the 
extra gas spill out on the ground,  you put it in a gas can and set it in 
the trunk. Sometime extra fat is good for when you run low on 
calories...too much just makes you heavy.
comments.author: Melissa Lewis

comments.text:
Calorie is just heat, that is how much heat your body takes to metabolise 
that food or drink

captions.text:
This episode of Dnews is brought to you by
Domain.com.

Zero-calorie foods are all the rage these
days - but are they REALLY zero calories?

And is it even possible for a food to HAVE
zero calories?

Hey guys, Tara here for Dnews - and I’m
sure a lot of you out there drink diet soda

on occasion, and if so - perhaps you’ve
found yourself wondering at times, “How

is it possible that this has zero calories?”
Or for that matter, how can any food have
zero calories?

It’s an interesting question, and the truth
is - they really can’t.

Aside from water, there is no truly zero calorie
food or beverage. And here’s why you probably
didn’t know that.

First off, most foods labeled as having “zero
calories” - actually DO contain a small

amount of calories. But as long as it’s
less than 5, then the FDA legally allows manufacturers

to round down - meaning a food with 4.9 calories,
can still be listed as having zero.
Splenda, the “zero calorie sweetener,”

actually has 3.4 calories per packet. But
for an even better example, let’s look at

this product: I Can’t Believe It’s Not
Butter spray. It’s advertised as a non-fat,

zero-calorie food with a serving size of 5
sprays. But it’s actually not zero-calorie,

it contains 4 calories for every 5 sprays.
And when you consider the fact that its main

ingredient, soybean oil - contains about 120
calories per tbsp, then that means the entire

bottle - has almost 900 calories, even though
it’s advertising suggests that it is a zero
calorie food.

So misleading labels are definitely part of
the problem. Another problem is the myth perpetuated

around “negative calorie foods.” These
are things like celery or cucumbers, that

contain very few calories - and it’s a common
misconception that your body expends more

energy digesting them, than the amount of
calories it takes in. Unfortunately, there’s
really no science to back that up.

Let’s go back to the example of celery.
A single stalk of celery has 6 calories, and

the “thermic effect” of celery - which
is the percentage of its calories you burn

by digesting it - is around 8%. 8% of 6 calories
is about half of a calorie - which means that

even after you account for digestion, your
net calorie consumption is still 5 ½. Obviously

that’s negligible in the long run, but it
proves an important point.

Foods with the highest thermic effect, are
proteins - which still only have a thermic

effect of around 20-35%. Meaning there are
no truly negative-calorie foods or beverages.

Except… for ice water. Ice water technically
has zero calories, but your body has to expend

extra energy to bring it back up to your normal
body temperature - and for 8 oz of water,

that burns about 8 calories. So theoretically,
if you were drinking 8 8oz glasses of ice

water a day, you’d be burning about 64 calories
a day - for a year, that equates to 6 ½ pounds.

Now as far as weight loss is concerned, it’s
minimal - but of course the other benefits
from drinking that much water definitely aren’t.

Now, what about foods that are heavy in mass,
but claim to have zero or very low calories?

How do those work? Well, the idea is that
those foods are made up of ingredients your

body simply can’t break down. If you were
to think about it in very abstract terms,

you could almost liken it to eating a piece
of plastic - your body can’t digest it,

so it simply passes through your system, meaning
you don’t consume or burn calories from
eating it.

Now most of the time, foods that are like
that, contain a lot of fiber, which is indigestible

by humans - although we still consume it,
because it keeps our intestines flowing and

healthy. So if you were to eat a big, heavy
hunk of food that was almost entirely fiber,

it would still have an extremely low calorie
count, because your body can’t absorb any
of it.

So you see, the idea of a zero calorie food
- is pretty much a misconception. Almost all

foods, even those labeled as “zero calorie”
- do contain a small amount of calories. And

the only true “negative calorie” food
- is water. Which isn’t even a food. EVERYTHING
WE KNOW IS WRONG!

Switching gears for a second, if you’ve
been thinking about starting up your own blog

or website, then why not check out domain.com?
When you buy a domain name from Domain.Com,

you’re also buying the power to influence
and control what people find when they search
for you online.

Domain.com is affordable, reliable, and easy-to-use,
and let’s face it - no domain extension

will help you tell your story like a .COM
or .NET domain name.

Better yet, the guys over at Domain.Com have
set us up with a special offer, just for you

lovely Dnews viewers. All you have to do is
enter the coupon code DNEWS at checkout, and

you’ll get 15% off Domain.com’s already
affordable domain names and web hosting.
So when you think domain names, think Domain.Com.

In the meantime, let us know in the comments
what you think of this episode - and if there

are any other misconceptions about food you’d
like cleared up. That’s it for me, but as
always - thank you guys for watching!

title: How Can Something Have Zero Calories?
